comment: A very satisfying whiskey, the ageing has taken a lot of the natural bite out of it. A younger version might better appeal to the Irish whiskey drinkers palette.
Similar to Bushmills 21. Intense, nettly and long finish. The 12 year old I really like, but this adds a whole other dimension of depth.
Good but almost too subtle to taste.  And wicked spendy.
If you heard an Irish person describe this, they'd say "gargeous!" Has a lot going on, but very well balanced. A real treat.
Very fruity taste with extremely smooth finish.
Crazy long, smooth finish.  Better than 12, but not enough separation to justify cost.

There are two cherished euros in my house one is this beauty (and frankly my favorite to drink) and the other being lagavulin 16. Two completely differing tastes but each amazing for their respectable character..
Slight spice.  No buttery taste like the other Red Breast years.  Sweet, somewhat fruity notes.
Honeydew melon with a long and smooth finish.
In my opinion the best it's moreish thanks to the celtic whiskey shop in Dublin for the introduction to it
Not as good as the regular Redbreast
Had a taste and it was amazing! Very rare but something I would love to have again. if you see it at a bar, take advantage.
Love it. Don't hate, I like it better than the Middleton for sharing w friends.
Very smooth. Too fruity and floral for my taste though.
Awesome flavor, but a bit hot for my tastes...
Much less buttery than the 12 and the 15, very long and vey smooth.
If you like Irish Whiskey, this is an excellent example. For some reason, this needs to breathe for a long time for me to fully enjoy. For my money, I'd stick with Redbreast 15.
Perhaps I would have appreciated this more if I hadn't sampled it towards the end of the evening at WhiskyFest New York 2015, but by that time I was bored of all the sherry finishes.
if it was only a higher abv.still a lovely whiskey.very sweet with a touch of spice.
[Whisky Live Paris 2015]...I wish I had tasted more...maybe next year?!
Old cheese, creamy, fudge, depth and warmth
Taste pops on the front with all kinds of flavors think pop rocks. It is flat on the end. Not something i would keep
Very interesting flavour. Candy like taste.

What a complex nose. Everything from smoked meat to fruity sherbet. Bread as well. Definite pot still malt smell, but so much more. Smooth on the tongue. This tastes like concentrated peach juice, that's the predominant flavor. Some smoke, some toast, some toffee, every sip brings something else. Some lingering bitter chocolate. Long finish. Good stuff. 6/13/17

It doesn’t get much better. After tasting a couple of standards in my cabinet, I go back to this to understand what a gold standard tastes like. Enjoy if you can afford it. I paid $180 US at the distillery in Cork county. 
Rich and fruity.
Nose. Sweet heat, vanilla, fruity, leather
Mouth feel warm, spicy, leather, 
pears,
A perfect sipping whiskey
Finish, buttery on tongue 
Ex bourbon and first fill sherry casks
Brought a bottle home from Middleton distillery in Cork Co Ireland

Nose: strong
Taste: Feels creamy, like Kahlua. Sweet, vanilla. 
Long finish. Lingers on the tip of tongue, and hangs out in the chest for a while. 

Very good whisky.
Thick and heavy with definite pear eve I can taste. Had on rocks.
Wow, I'm not entirely sure what to make of this yet. Very fruit-forward - lots of mango and coconut. Long finish with an almost medicinal taste. I need more time getting to know this whisky.

Maybe built it up too much in my head. Will try again in a month or so.
        
        *edit* - is amazing. Maybe not $300 a bottle amazing but it flirts with the worth of the price tag. Mango is an unexpected flavor in any whisky in my opinon but this stuff is loaded with it and it is delicious. Easy 5 star.
Yum. Very smooth. Spicy with notes of dried fruit, sherry, and nuts.
Easily my favorite Irish whisky, it’s just real smooth but lights up the pallet
Had at barrel on high street in Columbus. $80 a pour. Very smooth and delicious
This might be #2 for 2018, but it's the best I ever had. He put me to bed, was gone in the morning, but left me wanting more.

Redbreast 12 was the first distilled spirit that nearly brought tears to my eyes. That moment where any of us destined to fall in love with Aqua Vitae say "oh I think I get it" . It's not as complex as a knock out single malt from the Scots but it is instead its own road. If a good scotch is the smartest guy you know that is as comfortable discussing politics as they are the fine arts and always seems to know a little bit about everything; then the Redbreast line up is your buddy that's always well dressed and polite and is a man of a few, carefully considered words. (For theatrical affect he's obviously wearing a woolen Irish sweater and a tweed cap). This 21 year old is the finest example of that. It's clearly Redbreast but it is the head of the family/older brother that's making the call on where you're going for dinner. It is so bold and reassured of itself that it commands your clear attention. On the nose it's dried fruit, and leather. On the palate those are there as well but a pine/menthol note comes through midway and sticks around through the finish. Lovely, satisfying Pot Still mouthfeel. Creamy and pleasant. The finish is medium long in length with more dried fruit (fig?) to go along with that spearmint pepperiness. This is very unique stuff, it tastes like nothing else. Highly recommended. 98\100. What can I say he's not your showiest friend buts he's almost certainly your coolest.
For a single pot Irish this is fun, agressive, rich and full of flavor. An excelent top shelf Irish whiskey for most anyone. The more you explore it the more there is to unpack.

It’s the Redbreast challenge: can anything be better than their 12yo cask strength? Hefty price tag aside, the dram seems innocuous enough: orangey-amber, smelling of hay, honey and just a hint of turpentine. The flavour, though, is so stunning in its length and complexity it’s difficult to unravel it all. Less fiery than the 12yo, it doesn’t call for water but benefits from a drop anyhow. Peachy sweetness is followed by dried fig fruit, then darker notes still: black licorice, pipe tobacco, spiced rum. Fabulous though it is, I have to admit it: I’d rather have four bottles of 12yo CS than one of this. Then again, each sip of this extraordinary Irish whiskey lasts so long, the bottle will probably last me a lifetime.
Strong stone fruit to start with a surprising peppery finish
Very fruity with a taste of guava and other tropical fruits.  Incredible smooth and complex.
Has a taste of ammonia and I think overpriced.
Sherry nose is quite wonderful. Simple sip of this whiskey will give you the strenght of irishman and amazing experience. Tastes even better in Ireland.

Broke out this bottle for Christmas Eve dinner. This is a very good whiskey with different interesting notes. Some fruit notes and a hint of coconut ( not sure how that happens). While very good and a little better than my favorite Lustau Edition the price is quite high.
complex, great flavor profile. Deep and rich
Good gracious! This is Irish Whiskey perfection in a glass. I just wish they had a CS version of this, but it's dessert--rich, full, lush, stonefruit and cereal. So good!

Nez: des épices d'automne, du citron, du sirop de fruit en canne et du sherry.

Bouche: bleuet, abricot, pomme verte sûre, cuivré, très très doux, épice de cannelle plus effacé.

Finale: moyennement longue, sur ce gout cuivré-fruité et des notes de vieux sherry.

overall: le bouquet et complet. Très complexe et gouté. Une texture bien grasse et gouteuse qui fait ressortir les arômes de façon prononcé. +1 pour l'originalité aromatique. Tout simplement fabuleux... Je crois que cette bouteille plaira autant à l'amateur débutant que l'amateur avancé. Peut-être que les Sherry-bomb lovers seront déçu des notes "trop" subtile du sherry.  Peut-être que les amateurs de tourbe n'y verront que peu d'intérêt. Moi, j'y vois une oeuvre d'art en bouteille, un équilibre parfait d'arôme sans domination, une fraicheur et une douceur qui n’affaiblis aucunement le portrait aromatique. Simplement le meilleur Irish que j'ai goûté jusqu'à ce jour. Bref, je ne peux que donner un minimum de 98%.
Beautifully smooth and easy to sip on the rocks or straight up.
I need to drink a lot more of this to put my finger on the taste

Tropical fruits and tropical fruits
Exceptionnal
Underwhelming.... not as sweet and Carmel forward as the 12. More complex, but it is a musty complexity opposed to a scotch complexity.
Complex and delicious. I don’t know why this whiskey doesn’t get more love. It’s absolutely outstanding. Top notch
not really Smokey but spicy smooth, with water it's still spicy as hell, not really hot per say but very unique and flavorful
Fantastic Irish style whisky with strong fruit notes throughout (I tasted apricot).

Nose - Fresh tropical fruits, nuts and rich dried fruit.
Taste - Soft vanilla, taste of the oak and sherry plus the typical Pot Still spices. Very fruity and creamy.
Finish - Lingers a long time - creamy.

This is a top class whiskey - one of the best and a personal favourite.

(credit to published reviews - on which I built mine)

Nose: Sweet, oaky
Palette: Honey, but not overly sweet. Cinnamon, slightly peppery and oak 
Finish: Long and smooth, stone fruit, mangoes/peaches at the very finish. 

I had to try this whiskey based on everything I read. I was not disappointed in the least. Amazing overall, the stone fruit at the finish sealed it for me...
As close to perfection as you’ll get.
August 4, 2019 at Lions Pub in Vancouver. Served in a tasting glass. Nose of fruit, suggestion of leather. Very pleasantly fruity with oak notes. About as nice as an unpeated whiskey can be.
The best whiskey I've ever had.
Complex, sweet, smooth. One of the best Irish whiskeys you can buy
Amazing whisky Fruity deep with long aftertaste
Amazing flavors. Very fruity and so refined. It's like drinking velvet.
This is an outstandingly good Irish.  Unusual aroma out of the bottle but extremely smooth and flavorful with no hint of aftertaste.  I’m a rum drinker but this might make me switch.

Bushmills 21 is great, but this is the better Irish 21-year old. Rich and full, more strength, and the single pot still gives it that extra fresh flavor combined with fruit and vanilla from the oak. 95

Does it get any better than this? Answer:no. Incredible whiskey.

RB 21 tops Bushmills 21. More flavor, more complex, more proof. Don’t pass on this...

Nose is sweet but not identifiable as a Irish, reminds me of a bourbon nose with caramel up front finishing with burn. Spicy up front of the pallete with a metallic tinge indicative of a very old whisky. Smooth floral finish but lacks comexity. Value is a problem here as with all 20+ year whiskeys.
I can’t think of anything else I’d want in an Irish whiskey. Excellent.

Holy hell. Was not expecting to enjoy this as much as I am. 21 years is a long time, sometimes too long. But it serves this well. Dried fruits on the nose, soft vanilla and toasted oak with a creamy mouthfeel. Wunderbar.
If you enjoy the Redbreast 12 CS then this is paradise.

I had long awaited to finally taste this dram. The incredibly famous Redbreast 21yo was supposed to be the most chocolaty-amazing whiskey in all the land. 

I was at an Irish Bar, and this was the most expensive glass of them all. $50 was the price to pay for this tasting moment. And when they brought the whiskey, i felt it didn't have the aroma i expected. Actually it took a few minutes to open up... then it was wonderful.

Well, lets do this:

On the nose: Vanilla mixed wirh grain whiskey. Coffee. Burnt caramel but not as creme brulee.  Cocoa. Dark chocolate; Peanut butter, Definitively buttery. Butterfinger chocolate and Dulce de leche. Such a treat. 

On the palate, explosion of chocolate and Butter. Maybe peanutbutter. Very thick, lots of character. Aftertaste is spicy with clove notes. 

Overall this is a fantastic dram, BUT YOU MUST LET IT BREATH. Its overall sensation is that you are having a Milka Caramel Chocolate. 93 out of 100. Sláinte!
Most delicious after my bottle has opened up even more after 12 weeks.
Honey, rich, mouth-watering. Complex stuff. Excellent.

What a thing of beauty. Nose is vibrant with hazelnut, fig, almond, white chocolate, white pepper, leather, straw, and oak.

Lively, oily mouthfeel, supple fruit on the tongue that follows through so well from the nose. Drier than the nose with more spice as it lingers....and it lingers. 

What a beautiful dram.

Falling out of love with this one, though I never really preferred it to the 12CS anyway. 
Nothing “wrong” with it per se but to me it ends up a bit dull and without any specific redeeming qualities that would justify its premium. 
Tyrconnell 16, RB12CS, Powers Johns Lane, and Green Spot are all Irish bottles I prefer to this, and all are significantly cheaper.

Nose: Very rich.  Some honey, vanilla, even some peppermint. Varnish as well, which has never smelled so delicious. Lots of fresh stone fruits here. 

Palate: Wow.  Delicious oily mouthfeel.  This is a flavour explosion. Hard to even keep track of everything going on here. Prunes and ripe plums, cinnamon and black pepper as well coming through. Tons of cereal notes. 

Finish: Long chewy finish with lots of cereal notes. Nice tannins linger on the sides of the tongue. 

This is a spectacular whisky.  I'm a huge fan of Redbreast 12 but this is a different league.
Shit, it's like a fir Christmas tree wrapped in velvet, smooth like honey, rich, smooth,
Love this super sweet and rich.

This gorgeous Irish whiskey is liquid gold or melted sunlight in both taste and color (whichever metaphor better strikes your heartstrings.) And exceedingly thin viscous legs dance slowly down the glass.

The nose is overall fruity and floral with notes of honey and grass, orchard fruits, orange, green grapes, and salted caramel.

The palate has a creamy mouthfeel and is very fruity with notes of tangerine, sweet red apple, plum, blackberry jam, and cantaloupe melon.

The finish is long, with a soft black tea tannic aftertaste.

Oh my gosh. This whiskey was another treat from a friend and I am quite blessed to have been able to savor a sample. It is amazing to me what can be done to whiskey to alter the end product so vastly! I believe the saying is true, “There are no bad whiskeys, just exceptional ones.” However compared to this exceptional gem, some whiskeys don’t stand a chance! I highly recommend trying this Irish blessing and would personally love to have it again! Thank you Midleton Distillery! Sláinte!

Nose: sherry galore, ripe red berries, sourish honey, pineapple, red grapes, light chocolate. All in all rich and more fresh instead of an expected sweetness. 

Palate: very interesting. Next to a sour fruitiness I got a nice pine tree resin taste. That’s new - never had that before. Also a heavy sweet cranberry jam taste, spicey cloves and some intense dry wood. 

Finish: long, a little numbing white pepper burn, a fruity bitterness like when you bite into the peel of an orange. 

A very deep and rich Irish whisk(e)y. Really something different. Even if it came across a little rough the experience is very unique and interesting.
Complex and lingering.  Some fruitiness of the 12 has returned but transformed from citrus to dense tropical.  A highly intense bready nose.  Finishes with toffee and clove.
